com.badlogic.gdx.graphics
Interface Mesh

public interface Mesh

A Mesh, either indexed or non-indexed. A mesh contains vertices composed of positions, normals, colors and texture coordinates. Additionally it can have indices which refer to those vertices for optimization. To define a mesh various methods are provided which operate much like their OpenGL immediate mode counter parts. Use normal, color and texture coordinate methods before you define a vertex.

For more fine grained control you can directly acces the arrays holding the vertex data. If you do so you have to set the Mesh dirty manually by calling Mesh.setDirty() after you are done manipulating the vertices. Additionally you have to use the Mesh.render() method that demands the number of vertices to use to be given.

A Mesh has to be disposed after it is no longer used.

Author:
mzechner

            float y,
            float z)
Define a vertex.

Parameters:
x - The x coordinate
y - The y coordinate
z - The z coordinate

color

void color(float r,
           float g,
           float b,
           float a)
Define a vertices color. All components must be in the range [0,1].

Parameters:
r - The red component
g - The green component
b - The blue component
a - The alpha component

texCoord

void texCoord(float u,
              float v)
Define a vertices texture coordinates.

Parameters:
u - The u component
v - The v component

normal

void normal(float nx,
            float ny,
            float nz)
Define a vertices normal. The normal must be normalized to unit length.

Parameters:
nx - The x component
ny - The y component
nz - The z component

index

void index(int... indices)
Define the meshes indices. This can be called multiple times, e.g. for each face of the mesh.

Parameters:
indices - The indices

render

void render(Mesh.PrimitiveType type,
            int numVertices,
            int offset)
Renders the mesh using the given primitive type.

Parameters:
type - The primitive type
numVertices - The number of vertices to render
offset - if indexed then this is the offset into the index array, otherwise it is the offset into the vertex array
